Physical examination shows a swollen and erythematous metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint of the big toe. Joint aspiration and crystal analysis shows thin, tapered, needle-shaped intracellular crystals that are strongly negatively birefringent. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Sodium      135 mEq/L    
 Potassium      3.2 mEq/L    
 Chloride      95 mEq/L    
 Creatinine      1.0 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and joint aspirate are consistent with gout, which results from tissue deposition of monosodium urate crystals due to supersaturation. Clinically, gout presents with arthritis (gouty arthritis) or tophi (chronic tophaceous gout) and the most common area of the body to be affected is the first toe. Thiazide diuretics are secreted by the same secretory system that secretes uric acid into the proximal tubule. Here they compete with the secretion of uric acid, therefore increasing uric acid levels in the blood and increasing risk of a gout attack.

Other adverse effects associated with thiazide diuretics include hypercalcemia, hyperglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperlipidemia. Chronic therapy is often associated with potassium wasting since an increased sodium load is presented to the collecting tubules; the cortical collecting tubules compensate by reabsorbing sodium and excreting potassium.

Thiazide diuretics can also induce hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. It happens because an increased concentration of sodium ions in the collecting duct makes the collecting duct secrete more potassium and hydrogen ions from the blood and into the urine. People with allergic reactions to sulfonamide medications may develop an allergic reaction to thiazides and thiazide-like diuretics.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Amlodipine :
Incorrect: Calcium channel blockers can lower uric acid levels and are likely to reduce the risk of a gout attack. 
✅ Hydrochlorothiazide :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Spironolactone :
Incorrect:  Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and is likely to cause hyperkalemia (as opposed to this patient’s hypokalemia). Its other side effects include gynecomastia and antiandrogenic effects. It would not precipitate a gout attack. 
❌ Smoking :
Incorrect: Smoking is associated with decreased risk of gout due to decreased production of uric acid. 
❌ Allopurinol :
Incorrect: Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is prescribed as a prophylactic treatment for gout. It would not precipitate a new onset of gout.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office because of severe left flank pain for the past week. The pain has an intermittent squeezing quality, radiates to the groin, and is associated with nausea and vomiting. The patient does not have abdominal pain or fever.  Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows severe left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness and urine dipstick reveals microscopic hematuria. Urinalysis shows crystals in the shape of an envelope. The patient is started on a medication that decreases urinary calcium excretion. Which of the following segments of the nephron is affected by this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with flank pain, hematuria, and envelope-shaped stones on urinalysis most likely have calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis. Thiazide diuretics decrease calcium excretion in the distal convoluted tubule and are an effective treatment option for prevention.

Thiazides inhibit sodium chloride transport by apical Na-Cl cotransporters by competing for a chloride site on the transporter, in the early segment of the distal convoluted tubule. Although thiazides inhibit the reabsorption of sodium in this segment, they increase the reabsorption of calcium. Moreover, calcium reabsorption is also increased along the proximal tubule as a result of reduced extracellular fluid volume, which enhances proximal reabsorption. 

In addition, thiazides are also known to decrease serum magnesium levels. Hypomagnesemia has been suggested to result from potassium deficiency, increased passive magnesium secretion, or decreased active magnesium transport in the distal convoluted tubule. 

Loop diuretics, on the other hand, can cause hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia by decreasing the electrical gradient for magnesium and calcium reabsorption and increasing urinary magnesium and calcium excretion.   

Option Analysis

❌ A :
Incorrect: Acetazolamide works by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, blocking NaHCO3, and water reabsorption and resulting in urinary bicarbonate wasting. It does not decrease urinary calcium excretion. 
❌ B:
Incorrect: The descending loop of Henle carries fluid from the proximal tubule to the ascending loop of Henle. It allows reabsorption of water into the interstitial fluids to produce concentrated urine. No known drug effectively acts on this segment of the nephron. 
❌ C:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter and can cause hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia by decreasing the electrical gradient for magnesium and calcium reabsorption and increasing urinary magnesium and calcium excretion. 
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ E:
Incorrect: Potassium-sparing diuretics and aldosterone antagonists act on the collecting duct systems. They do not affect urine calcium excretion.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the gastroenterology clinic for a routine colonoscopy. The patient is found to have a tumor located in the sigmoid colon, which is infiltrating into the descending large intestine. Biopsies of the tumor are taken on colonoscopy and are found to be aggressive colonic adenocarcinoma. Molecular studies are pending. PET scan shows metastatic disease reaching lymph nodes and the portal system. Which of the following is the strongest prognostic factor and target for treating this patient’s colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a colonic adenocarcinoma with metastasis to the liver and peripheral lymph nodes. While several mutations are associated with the development of metastatic colorectal cancer, only BRAF is highly prognostic and targetable. 

BRAF is a key intermediary in the choices listed MAPK signaling cascade, leading to the activation of ERK (see image). Some colorectal cancers can develop a V600E mutation of BRAF, driving high ERK signaling output independently. Similar mutations in BRAF are common in melanomas and some thyroid cancers and are associated with more aggressive phenotypes.  Therefore, inhibition of BRAF signaling is a key aspect of treatment in these cancers, as it significantly stifles cell proliferation in aberrant cells. BRAF inhibition is seldom used alone and is often combined with inhibition of complement pathways of tumorigenesis, including EGFR, MEK, PI3K, and Wnt pathways. BRAF inhibitors include encorafenib, dabrafenib, and vemurafenib. Side effects of these medications include the development of skin abnormalities such as kerato-acanthomas, diarrhea, fatigue, and arthralgias.    

Option Analysis

❌ VEGF mutations :
Incorrect: VEGF mutations are common in many solid cancers. They have little clinical significance in diagnosing and treating metastatic colon cancer.  
✅ BRAF V600E mutations :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Age at initial diagnosis:
Incorrect: While age is an important aspect of colon cancer screening, age is not the strongest prognostic factor for patients who have metastatic colon cancer, nor is it targetable for therapy 
❌ Family history of disease :
Incorrect: While family history is an important factor in colon cancer screening, it is not the strongest prognostic factor for patients who have metastatic colon cancer, nor is it targetable for therapy. 
❌ Microsatellite instability :
Incorrect: Microsatellite instability (MSI) is associated with colon cancer and BRAF mutations; however, prognostically, having a BRAF mutation is more prognostically significant than MSI.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the oncology clinic to discuss a recent diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. Medical history is otherwise significant for hypertension, for which the patient takes lisinopril. Family history is significant for renal cell carcinoma in the patient’s father. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable. The patient asks the oncologist why his “immune system is not attacking the cancer.” The oncologist explains several immune system regulators, such as the programmed death-1 ligand and receptor (PDL1 and PD-1, respectively) and cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4 (CTLA-4). Which of the following correctly describes how the cancer cells could be evading the immune system?

choices.text: CD28 on cancer cells binds CTLA-4 on T-cells
CTLA-4 on cancer cells binds CD28 on T-cells
PD-1 ligands on cancer cells bind PD-1 receptors on immune cells
PD-1 receptors on cancer cells bind PD-1 ligands on immune cells
p53 protein upregulation by cancer cells

questions.solution:
There are many ways tumor cells can evade the immune system. Normally, the immune system has several “checkpoint” functions that help prevent it from attacking its cells. Immune cells, such as regulatory T-lymphocytes, play a crucial role in this process. Several examples of regulatory checkpoints include co-stimulation signals for activation, programmed cell death, and downregulation of T-lymphocytes. Tumor cells can exploit these by expressing molecules that prevent their destruction by downregulating these regulatory immune cells.

One common example is the programmed death-1 pathway. Normally the PD-1 ligand (PDL1) is expressed in cells such as T-cells and NK cells. It binds to the PD-1 receptor (PD-1) on activated T-cells and B-cells to downregulate activated T-cells while promoting regulatory T-cells. 

Over the last decade, many new immunotherapy medications have been developed and approved for use as immune checkpoint inhibitors in cancers. Several examples include CTLA-4 inhibitors (e.g. ipilimumab), PDL1 inhibitors (e.g. atezolizumab) and PD-1 inhibitors (e.g. nivolumab, pembrolizumab).   

Option Analysis

❌ CD28 on cancer cells binds CTLA-4 on T-cells :
Incorrect: CD28 is a receptor found on T-cells that binds to CD80 (B7) for co-stimulatory signaling activation. CTLA-4 competes with CD28 to downregulate T-cell activation. CD28 does not bind to CTLA-4 (they are homologous receptors). 
❌ CTLA-4 on cancer cells binds CD28 on T-cells :
Incorrect: CD28 is a receptor found on T-cells that binds to CD80 (B7) for co-stimulatory signaling activation of T-cells. CTLA-4 competes with CD28 to downregulate T-cell activation. CD28 does not bind to CTLA-4 (they are homologous receptors). 
✅ PD-1 ligands on cancer cells bind PD-1 receptors on immune cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ PD-1 receptors on cancer cells bind PD-1 ligands on immune cells :
Incorrect: Cancer cells generally produce the PD-1 ligand, which binds to PD-1 receptors on T-cells, downregulating their activity. PDL1 expression on tumor cells can often be measured.  
❌ p53 protein upregulation by cancer cells :
Incorrect: p53 is a regulatory protein involved in DNA repair, apoptosis, and others. In general, it has anti-cancer properties (as it does things such as inhibit tumor angiogenesis).

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dyspnea. The patient had worsening shortness of breath over the past week. Past medical history is significant for dyslipidemia, hypertension, and tobacco use (60-pack-year smoking history). Medications include pravastatin and valsartan. Temperature is 100 ºF (37.8 ºC), pulse is 66/min, blood pressure is 139/87, respirations are 20/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 92% on room air. Physical examination shows a male in mild respiratory distress who can speak full sentences. Lung auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds on the left posterior chest wall. Chest x-ray shows a large left pleural effusion. The patient undergoes left-sided thoracentesis and is found to have an exudative effusion. Post-procedure chest x-ray shows a large left lung mass where the effusion was previously located. A lung biopsy is performed, and pathologic analysis returns as non-small cell lung cancer. The decision is made to start atezolizumab; which of the following is the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Inhibition of cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein-4 (CTLA-4)
Inhibition of DNA repair by topoisomerases

questions.solution:
This patient has non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Treatment of NSCLC is usually some combination of chemotherapy, radiation, and surgery. In certain patients, especially those who are not good surgical candidates, immune checkpoint inhibitors are frequently used. Pathologic analysis of the biopsy tissue can test the malignant cells for how much PD-1 ligand (PDL1) they express.

PD-1 is an immune checkpoint molecule (receptor) expressed on T-cells. Certain malignancies can express PDL1, which binds PD-1 and inactivates T-cells, effectively avoiding destruction by the immune system. PDL1 inhibitors (e.g. atezolizumab) bind this ligand on cancer cells. This prevents the PDL1 of cancer cells from binding PD-1 and downregulating that immune cell, allowing the immune system to attack malignant cells.

Since PDL1 (and PD-1) inhibitors disrupt normal immune system regulation, side effects similar to autoimmune phenomena can occur. Common side effects include colitis, thyroiditis (often manifesting as hypothyroidism), and skin rash.   

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein-4 (CTLA-4) :
Incorrect: CTLA-4 inhibitors (e.g. ipilimumab) block CTLA-4, which normally downregulates the immune response. These can allow the immune system to attack malignant cells. 
❌ Inhibition of DNA repair by topoisomerases :
Incorrect: Topoisomerase inhibitors prevent DNA repair by binding to topoisomerase enzymes.  Examples include etoposide and irinotecan. 
❌ Intercalation of DNA strands :
Incorrect: Medications such as doxorubicin can insert between DNA strands, preventing DNA replication. 
✅ Inhibition of programmed death-1 (PD-1) ligand :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inhibition of programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor :
Incorrect: Some cancer cells express the PD-1 ligand (PDL1), which binds to the PD-1 receptor on T-cells, evading destruction by T-cells. Nivolumab and pembrolizumab are the most common inhibitors of the PD-1 receptor.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the oncology clinic for a follow-up. The patient was diagnosed with metastatic melanoma two months ago and was started on nivolumab. Repeat computed tomography (CT) and positron emission tomography (PET) imaging performed last week showed the progression of the metastatic lesions. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable. After a long discussion with the oncologist, the decision is made to start ipilimumab; which of the following is the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Inhibition of cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein-4 (CTLA-4)
Inhibition of DNA repair by topoisomerases

questions.solution:
This patient has metastatic melanoma; the prognosis of metastatic melanoma has improved with immunotherapy but is still limited. After diagnosis, patients need thorough evaluation for metastatic lesions as patients are at high risk for unrecognized lesions.

Upon diagnosis, patients are assessed for mutations in the BRAF gene (e.g. V600E) and may sometimes receive medications targeted toward these mutations. The other most common regimen is programmed death receptor inhibitors (PD-1), which include nivolumab and pembrolizumab with or without a CTLA-4 inhibitor, such as ipilimumab. CTLA-4 is an immune checkpoint molecule that competes with CD28 (a T-cell stimulating agent) and binds to CD80 (B7) and CD86 on antigen-presenting cells to downregulate them.

The PD-1 and CTLA-4 combination regimen can cause severe diarrhea and is not always well-tolerated by patients. PD-1 inhibitors, like other immunotherapeutic agents, can lead to autoimmune phenomena since they inhibit T-cells' proper functioning.   

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein-4 (CTLA-4) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inhibition of DNA repair by topoisomerases :
Incorrect: Topoisomerase inhibitors prevent DNA repair by binding to topoisomerase enzymes.  Examples include etoposide and irinotecan. 
❌ Intercalation of DNA strands :
Incorrect: Medications such as doxorubicin can insert between DNA strands, preventing DNA replication. 
❌ Inhibition of programmed death-1 (PD-1) ligand :
Incorrect: Some cancer cells express the PD-1 ligand (PDL1), which binds to the PD-1 receptor on T-cells, evading destruction by T-cells. Atezolizumab is a common inhibitor of the PD-1 ligand. 
❌ Inhibition of programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor :
Incorrect: Some cancer cells express the PD-1 ligand (PDL1), which binds to the PD-1 receptor on T-cells, evading destruction by T-cells. Nivolumab and pembrolizumab are the most common inhibitors of the PD-1 receptor.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the office for two days with fever, chills, and perineal pain. The patient has had frequent urges to urinate and pain with micturition. The patient also reports mild lower abdominal discomfort. She is not sexually active. The patient was treated with an antibiotic for a presumed urinary tract infection 2 weeks ago. The patient’s medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows lower abdominal fullness and mild tenderness. Urinalysis is shown below. Urine culture and sensitivity demonstrates growth of >100,000 colony-forming units/mL of Escherichia coli resistant to gentamicin. Which of the following best describes the most likely underlying resistance mechanism of this bacteria? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Urinalysis   
 Specific gravity     1.020    
 Blood     trace    
 Leukocyte esterase     positive    
 Nitrites     positive    
 Leukocytes     100/hpf    
 Erythrocytes     4-6/hpf    
 Dysmorphic RBCs     Absent    
 Casts     none

choices.text: Mutation in protein in 30S ribosomal subunit
Chromosome encoded mutation in DNA gyrase
Production of a low-affinity penicillin-binding protein (PBP)
Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase
Replace alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan

questions.solution:
Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking the formation of the initiation complex and interfering with the aminoacyl binding site on the 30S ribosomal subunit. Ultimately, this results in misreading of mRNA and inhibition of translocation.

An important mechanism of resistance to aminoglycosides is the chromosomal mutation (methylation) in the gene that codes for the target protein in the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome. This mutation inhibits the ability of aminoglycosides to interfere with translation. Other common mechanisms include:

  •  Modification of the drugs chemical structure by plasmid-encoded phosphorylation, adenylylation and acetylation  
  •  Decreased permeability of the medication due to mutations in bacterial porin proteins.  


Option Analysis

✅ Mutation in protein in 30S ribosomal subunit :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chromosome encoded mutation in DNA gyrase :
Incorrect: Resistance to quinolone antibiotics is primarily mediated by chromosomal-encoded mutations that modify the bacterial DNA gyrase. 
❌ Production of a low-affinity penicillin-binding protein (PBP) :
Incorrect: Resistance to penicillins is caused by changes in the PBPs in the bacterial cell membrane.  
❌ Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase :
Incorrect: Decreased activity of bacterial catalase-peroxidase is the mechanism of mycobacterial resistance to isoniazid. Mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase activity is required to synthesize the active metabolite of isoniazid that inhibits the growth of M. tuberculosis. 
❌ Replace alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan :
Incorrect: Resistance to vancomycin is caused by a change in the peptide component of peptidoglycan from D-alanyl-D-alanine, to D-alanine-D-lactate.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman visits the office for a follow-up visit. She has no active complaints but reports three episodes of uncomplicated urinary tract infection in the past three months. She completed an antibiotic course each time prescribed by a physician at a telemedicine appointment. She has a five-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her medications include metformin and lisinopril. Her HbA1c at her previous visit three months ago was 7.2%, when she was started on a drug known to improve glycemic control by increasing glucose-induced insulin secretion from the pancreas. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most likely drug prescribed to this patient?

choices.text: Inhibition of sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT 2) in proximal convoluted tubule
Blockade of potassium (K+) channels on pancreatic beta cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of multiple urinary tract infections is most likely due to the initiation of the hypoglycemic drug dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor.       

DPP-4 is a protease responsible for the breakdown of glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) (a type of incretin responsible for glucose-dependent insulin release from the pancreas). This class of drugs inhibits DDP4 from inactivating GLP-1 and allows it to exert its effects for a longer duration, causing glucose-dependent insulin release from pancreatic beta cells. Common examples include linagliptin, sitagliptin, and saxagliptin. It is usually used with metformin, a thiazolidinedione, or a sulfonylurea when adequate glycemic control cannot be achieved. Monotherapy is only indicated in patients with intolerance (e.g. lactic acidosis) or contraindications to metformin (e.g. chronic kidney disease). Common adverse effects include respiratory and urinary tract infections.   

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT 2) in proximal convoluted tubule :
Incorrect: Sodium-glucose co-transporter two inhibitors (e.g. canagliflozin) inhibits the SGLT 2 in proximal convoluted tubules, preventing the reabsorption of glucose in blood. Although excessive glucose excretion in urine increases the risk of developing urinary tract infection, SGLT-2 inhibitors do not affect insulin secretion by the pancreas. 
❌ Blockade of potassium (K+) channels on pancreatic beta cells :
Incorrect: Sulfonylureas (e.g. glyburide) and meglitinides (e.g. repaglinide) act by blocking the potassium (K+) channels on pancreatic beta cells, resulting in glucose independent release of insulin. Common adverse effects include weight gain and lactic acidosis. It does not predispose to urinary tract infections. 
❌ Activation of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors gamma  :
Incorrect: Thiazolidinediones (e.g. pioglitazone) are synthetic ligands that bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma receptors leading to increased insulin sensitivity (not release) by upregulating the transcription of insulin-responsive genes in peripheral tissues (e.g., adipose tissue, skeletal muscles, and liver). Common adverse effects include weight gain and edema. 
❌ Inhibition of mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) :
Incorrect: Metformin inhibits mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD), leading to the  inhibition of gluconeogenesis by blocking pyruvate carboxylase, the first step of gluconeogenesis. It also increases glucose uptake in peripheral cells by increasing their sensitivity to insulin. It, however, does not affect insulin secretion by the pancreas. 
✅ Inhibition of enzyme dipeptidyl peptidase-4 :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic due to spotting in between regular menstrual cycles. The patient’s last menstrual cycle was 10 days ago. The bleeding occurs cyclically, during the same time every month. The patient has no abdominal pain and is not sexually active. Past medical history is significant for obesity, and seizure disorder diagnosed 6 months ago. Medications include oral contraceptive pills and recently prescribed phenobarbital.  BMI is 31 kg/m2. Pelvic examination reveals blood originating from the cervical os. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Aromatase conversion of estrogens to androgens

questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing breakthrough bleeding and spotting. She takes oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and has recently started phenobarbital. Phenobarbital, like all barbiturates, is an inducer of the cytochrome p450 enzyme family. By inducing cytochrome p450, drugs that are metabolized by cytochrome p450 may be more rapidly metabolized, causing drug failure in a dose-dependent manner. This is critical to remember for estrogen-based OCPs, as they have reduced effectiveness and an increased incidence of breakthrough bleeding when used in conjunction with cytochrome p450 inducers. Common inducers include certain antibiotics such as ampicillin, rifampin, tetracycline, and other medications such as barbiturates or phenytoin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cytochrome P450 induction :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cytochrome P450 inhibition :
Incorrect: Phenobarbital, like all barbiturates, is a cytochrome p450 activator, not inhibitor.  
❌ Malingering :
Incorrect: Malingering would involve the patient lying in order to deliberately attain personal gain. There is no obvious sign of malingering or desired personal gain in the vignette, and the patient’s symptoms are corroborated by blood found on the pelvic exam while being between menstrual cycles. 
❌ Aromatase conversion of estrogens to androgens :
Incorrect: Fatty tissue contains the enzyme aromatase, which converts estrogens to androgens. This is part of the underlying pathophysiology of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). While PCOS and severe obesity can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, this patient has no other symptoms of PCOS and a BMI of 29 kg/m2 alone is not likely to cause intermittent spotting.  
❌ Direct drug-drug interactions :
Incorrect: Phenobarbital is a barbiturate that induces the cytochrome p450 enzyme family. Estrogens provided by oral contraceptive pills are substrates of the cytochrome p450 family and do not interact with phenobarbital directly.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the family medicine clinic for evaluation of elevated blood glucose on routine laboratory testing. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Family history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus in the patient’s father. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 34 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory investigation shows fasting blood glucose of 160 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1c of 9.0%. A diagnosis of type II diabetes mellitus is established. In addition to dietary changes and exercise recommendations, the patient is started on a medication that reduces blood glucose levels by inhibiting hepatic gluconeogenesis and increasing peripheral tissue sensitivity to insulin. Which of the following is this medication's uncommon but severe side effect?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus and is initiated on metformin therapy. Lactic acidosis is an uncommon but severe side effect of metformin therapy.    

Metformin (biguanide), in the absence of contraindications, is a first line of therapy for treating type 2 diabetes mellitus. It lowers plasma glucose concentrations by decreasing hepatic gluconeogenesis. The exact mechanism remains unknown but is thought to result from the activation of AMP-dependent protein kinase (AMPK), which inhibits phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (via the inhibition of mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase). AMPK also causes the glucose transporter protein (GLUT4) within adipose and muscle tissues to embed into the plasma membrane, allowing glucose to enter. Moreover, metformin decreases intestinal absorption of glucose—the overall effect results in increased insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues and reduced blood glucose levels.    

Metformin is contraindicated in patients with renal insufficiency. The most common side effects of metformin include gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., diarrhea, vomiting) and weight loss (useful in obese diabetic patients). Lactic acidosis is a rare but severe side effect resulting from lactic acid accumulation in patients with compromised renal function (due to inadequate excretion).  



Option Analysis

✅ Lactic acidosis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Orthostatic hypotension :
Incorrect: Orthostatic hypotension, secondary to osmotic diuresis, is a severe adverse effect of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors (e.g. canagliflozin). These medications act on the renal tubule to prevent the reabsorption of glucose. Other common adverse effects of these medications include urinary tract infections, vulvovaginal candidiasis, and acute kidney injury. 
❌ Hypoglycemia :
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia is the most common side effect of insulin secretagogues (sulfonylureas and meglitinides) and synthetic insulin preparations. Metformin increases insulin sensitivity, decreases hepatic gluconeogenesis, and rarely causes hypoglycemia, making it the first-line agent for the treatment of diabetes in most cases. Moreover, these medications cause weight gain and should be avoided in this patient. 
❌ Heart failure  :
Incorrect: Fluid retention and heart failure (HF) exacerbation are the uncommon side effects of thiazolidinediones. This class of medications includes rosiglitazone and pioglitazone. They bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors and increase insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues, enhancing glucose uptake. They do not affect hepatic gluconeogenesis. 
❌ Acute pancreatitis :
Incorrect:  Acute pancreatitis is an uncommon but serious adverse effect of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) agonists (e.g., exenatide and liraglutide). These injectable hypoglycemic drugs cause glucose-dependent insulin secretion by binding to its receptors on pancreatic beta cells. They do not affect hepatic gluconeogenesis or peripheral insulin sensitivity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the cardiologist's office for a follow-up visit. He was recently started on an antiarrhythmic medication to prevent future episodes of atrial fibrillation. The patient has been feeling well and has no acute symptoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 48/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/72 mmHg. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. An electrocardiogram is performed and demonstrates QT-interval prolongation. Which medications were most likely used to treat this patient's atrial fibrillation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bradycardia and QT-interval prolongation after being initiated on medication to treat paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The only medication listed that satisfies both of these criteria is sotalol. 

Sotalol is classically described as a class III antiarrhythmic agent with class II antiarrhythmic properties. In other words, sotalol is both a β-blocker and a K+-channel blocker. 

The medication’s significant β-adrenergic blocking abilities can result in bradycardia, whereas the class III effects result in QT-interval prolongation. Metoprolol, propranolol, and carvedilol are β-blockers like sotalol, but these medications lack sotalol's class III K+-blocking effects and hence will not prolong the QT interval.   

Option Analysis

❌ Carvedilol:
Incorrect: Carvedilol is a β-blocker used to treat congestive heart failure, left ventricular dysfunction following a heart attack, and high blood pressure. While it can be used for rate control in atrial fibrillation and can cause bradycardia, it does not cause QT interval prolongation.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol is a class II β-blocker used to manage hypertension, angina pectoris, and myocardial infarction. It does not cause QT interval prolongation.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a class II antiarrhythmic drug (β-blocker) used to treat conditions including hypertension, angina pectoris, migraines, and hypertrophic subaortic stenosis. It does not cause QT interval prolongation.  
✅ Sotalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil is a class IV antiarrhythmic drug that serves as a slow calcium channel blocker. It is used to treat angina, arrhythmias, and essential hypertension.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to his primary care physician due to concerns regarding a persistent facial rash. The patient started noticing that the skin on the tip of his nose, cheeks, and chin had been turning "blue." The rash seems to worsen while he is out in the sun. He has otherwise been feeling well. Several weeks ago, he was given procainamide in the emergency department for atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. Medical history is also notable for congestive heart failure, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. He has a 10-pack-year smoking history and consumes one to two beers daily. Current medications include losartan, amiodarone, carvedilol, and warfarin. Physical examination reveals the findings below. Which of the following is the most likely precipitant of this patient’s clinical presentation? 


Image reproduced from DermNetNZ
questions.solution:
Blue-gray skin discoloration (ceruloderma) is a rare but classic side effect of amiodarone therapy, which is more common in males than females.  

Amiodarone is a lipophilic drug used in the treatment of arrhythmias. The mechanism of skin discoloration is mainly undefined but is thought to be due to brownish-yellow deposits of amiodarone, iron, and other substances (not including melanin or hemosiderin) in tissue histiocytes near dermal blood vessels. The discoloration appears in sun-exposed areas and is thought to be triggered by a UV-related hypersensitivity response. 

Class III antiarrhythmic medications generally carry several side effects, but most importantly, torsade de pointe due to QT interval prolongation. Unlike other class III antiarrhythmics, Amiodarone has several unique side effects apart from ceruloderma. Amiodarone acts as a hapten, which can induce pulmonary fibrosis, hepatotoxicity, and corneal microdeposits. For this reason, pulmonary and liver function testing may be obtained for patients starting amiodarone. In addition, amiodarone is 40% iodine by weight and has a propensity to be taken up by the thyroid gland and induce thyroid dysfunction. For this reason, baseline thyroid function tests should be obtained.     

Option Analysis

✅ Amiodarone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Procainamide:
Incorrect: Procainamide is a class I antiarrhythmic agent that can precipitate a lupus-like reaction. However, this side effect is dose-dependent and unlikely to be caused by a single dose of procainamide administered several weeks ago. Furthermore, this patient’s findings are more consistent with ceruloderma (blue-gray hyperpigmentation) rather than an erythematous lupus butterfly rash. 
❌ Hyperglycemia:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus is associated with acanthosis nigricans, which tend to appear brown-to-black, poorly defined, velvety areas of hyperpigmentation found within body folds. 
❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect: Warfarin can cause severe skin necrosis if it is not appropriately bridged with heparin. It is not known to cause ceruloderma (blue-gray hyperpigmentation). 
❌ Niacin deficiency:
Incorrect: Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency is associated with severe alcoholism and nutritional deficiency. Niacin deficiency can cause pellagra, which manifests with peeling, redness, scaling, and thickening of sun-exposed areas of skin.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the primary care office because of trouble with vision. Over the past two weeks, the patient has been experiencing intermittent episodes of blue-tinted vision, which resolve within a few hours each time. He woke up today with blurry vision in the right eye. There is no eye pain, conjunctival redness, or headache. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type II diabetes mellitus, and erectile dysfunction. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows afferent pupillary defect, decreased visual acuity, and optic disc edema in the right eye. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibition of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in renal tubule
Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 in the endothelial cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a transient, bluish visual discoloration, afferent pupillary defect, decreased visual acuity, and optic disc edema in the right eye, together with a history of erectile dysfunction, is most likely due to an adverse effect of a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor (e.g., sildenafil, vardenafil, tadalafil). These agents are first-line medical therapy for erectile dysfunction. They can also be used to treat pulmonary hypertension.    

PDE-5 is responsible for the breakdown of cGMP and is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors with a resultant decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to smooth muscle relaxation (by enhancing NO activity). The net result is pulmonary vasodilation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis.    

Therefore, PDE-5 inhibitors are usually indicated in the treatment of erectile dysfunction (enhances the erectile response to sexual stimulation), pulmonary hypertension (reduces pulmonary vascular resistance), and benign prostate hyperplasia (only tadalafil specifically). Common side effects include facial flushing, headache, dyspepsia, hearing loss, and hypotension (when used with nitrates or alpha-adrenergic blockers). Sildenafil cross-reacts with PDE-6 in the retina and can cause transient blue vision (as seen in this patient). Rarely, non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) can occur.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase :
Incorrect: Statins act by inhibiting hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase, leading to a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and an increase in LDL recycling. Common side effects include hepatotoxicity, gastrointestinal discomfort, and rash. The blue-tinted vision seen in this patient is not associated with stains. 
❌ Inhibition of mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase :
Incorrect: Metformin (used for diabetes mellitus) inhibits gluconeogenesis by inhibiting mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase. Side effects include weight loss, gastrointestinal upset, and possibly lactic acidosis. Blue-tinted vision is not associated with metformin. 
❌ Inhibition of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in renal tubule :
Incorrect: Sodium-glucose co-transporter two inhibitors (e.g. canagliflozin) act on the renal tubule to prevent the reabsorption of glucose. Common adverse effects include urinary tract infections, vulvovaginal candidiasis, hypotension, and acute kidney injury. They are not associated with visual disturbances. 
❌ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-3 in platelets :
Incorrect: Antiplatelet phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitors (e.g., cilostazol) inhibit platelet aggregation via increased cAMP in platelets. Common side effects include dizziness, headaches, palpitations, and gastrointestinal disturbance. They do not affect vision. 
✅ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 in the endothelial cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to chest pain which started an hour ago while playing soccer with his grandchild. He describes a crushing pain that radiates down the left arm and is rated as eight on a ten-point scale. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, and erectile dysfunction. Current medications include atorvastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and sildenafil. Family history is noncontributory. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily, drinks five to six beers on weekends, and does not use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 102/minute, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/89 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and cardiac examination shows no murmurs. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) is shown below. Which of the following medications, if administered, is most likely to result in serious complications in this patient? 


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with typical chest pain in combination with ECG findings of ST-elevation in anterior precordial leads is suggestive of ST-elevation myocardial (STEMI). Nitroglycerin administration should be avoided in this patient due to the risk of profound hypotension when given together with sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor.    

Nitrates are converted to nitric oxide, which promotes the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). An increase in cGMP leads to vascular smooth muscle relaxation. PDE-5 is normally responsible for the breakdown of cGMP and is inhibited by PDE-5 inibitors (e.g. sildenafil). PDE-5 inhibition causes a decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells. This results in the accumulation of cGMP, leading to excessive vasodilation and profound hypotension when used in combination with nitrates (which also cause accumulation of cGMP).    



Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin :
Incorrect: The antiplatelet effects of aspirin are significant in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS). 325 mg aspirin should be administered as part of initial management in all patients with suspected myocardial infarction (MI). 
❌ Clopidogrel :
Incorrect: Patients with ACS should receive dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and another antiplatelet agent (e.g., clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor) before primary percutaneous intervention (PCI) or fibrinolytic therapy. It can be safely administered to this patient. 
❌ Enoxaparin :
Incorrect: Enoxaparin, low molecular weight heparin, is indicated in ACS to prevent intraluminal clot extension, formation, and re-infarction. It should be avoided in patients with contraindication to anticoagulants (e.g., history of cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation, intracranial neoplasm) and used cautiously if any recent (within the past six months) thromboembolic stroke. 
❌ Fentanyl :
Incorrect: Adequate analgesia is important for managing pain and anxiety (with resultant tachycardia). Fentanyl can be safely administered to this patient. 
✅ Nitroglycerin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing sudden onset of palpitations. An initial electrocardiogram demonstrates paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia at a rate of 160/min. He is given several doses of adenosine without termination of the arrhythmia. The primary physician discusses the case with the on-call electrophysiologist, who recommends administering a medication which affects the cardiac action potential in the manner designated in the figure below. Which of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia refractory to management with adenosine. He is subsequently given a medication that exerts a strong sodium channel blockade with no effect on the duration of the action potential, which is consistent with the mechanism of action of a class IC antiarrhythmic medications. Among the answer choices, only propafone is from this medication class.        

Class I antiarrhythmics are divided into three major classes--A, B, and C. However, all of them work via sodium channel blockade. Sodium channel blockade slows the upstroke of the sodium-dependent action potential (phase 0) and subsequently prolongs the QRS interval.        

Moreover, some of the class I antiarrhythmics have an effect on potassium channels and alter the action potential duration. Group 1A prolongs the action potential duration (due to potassium channel inhibition), 1B shortens the duration (due to potassium channel activation), and 1C has no effect on action potential duration (no effect of potassium channels).        

Understanding which medications are associated with each class and their subsequent effect on the ventricular action potential is an important concept for Step 1.  



Option Analysis

✅ Propafenone :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a class IV antiarrhythmic medication that can be used for rate control in patients with supraventricular tachycardias. However, diltiazem does not affect the ventricular cardiac action potential and would not alter the slope of the initial upstroke.  
❌ Ibutilide:
Incorrect: Ibutilide is a class III antiarrhythmic medication and does not affect phase 0 of ventricular depolarization.  
❌ Procainamide  :
Incorrect: Procainamide exhibits moderate sodium channel blockade. However, it also has some potassium channel-blocking effects, which increase the action potential duration and effective refractory period.  
❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Of all the class I antiarrhythmic medications, lidocaine exhibits the weakest effect on sodium channel blockade and will also decrease the action potential duration.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department following a syncopal episode while at the grocery store. He experienced a sensation of light-headedness and fluttering in his chest before subsequently passing out. The patient states his medical history includes a "heart condition." Brief chart review demonstrates an echocardiogram performed one month ago, which shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 162/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 118/82 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a hyperdynamic precordium and bibasilar crackles on pulmonary auscultation. Initial ECG shows ventricular tachycardia with left axis deviation. He is subsequently initiated on an antiarrhythmic medication and admitted to the coronary care unit. On the second day of hospitalization, he is noted to have a blood pressure of 86/58 mm Hg and jugular venous distention. Laboratory studies show an elevated brain natriuretic protein level. Which of the following medications is the most likely precipitant of this patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of diminished cardiac output is given an antiarrhythmic agent and subsequently develops findings of acute heart failure. Of the medications listed, only disopyramide is known to induce acute decompensated heart failure in patients with known impaired cardiac contractility.        

Disopyramide is a class IA antiarrhythmic that is used most often to treat ventricular arrhythmias and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This class of drugs works by inhibiting voltage-dependent fast sodium channels in cardiac muscle cells. When an electrical current propagates down the heart and reaches a myocyte, the nearby fast sodium channels typically open and allow a large rush of sodium ions into the cell, quickly raising the charge of the inner cellular membrane from negative to positive. This influx of sodium ions is stopped by the closing of the channel's inactivation gate, which reacts more slowly to the depolarization than to the channel's opening function.        

By serving as a fast sodium channel blocker in both the atria and the ventricles, disopyramide is able to slow the speed at which the heart depolarizes as an organized unit, and also decrease the strength of the heart's contractions. As such, one of disopyramide's feared complications is acute heart failure, and thus it cannot be used in patients with impaired systolic function.   

Option Analysis

✅ Disopyramide:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Lidocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic that works by blocking sodium channels and preferentially affects ischemic tissue and Purkinje fibers. Its notable side effects include paresthesias, seizures, respiratory depression, and central nervous system depression. However, it would not account for this patient’s decompensated heart failure. 
❌ Mexiletine:
Incorrect: Mexiletine is a class IB antiarrhythmic that works by blocking sodium channels and preferentially affects ischemic tissue and Purkinje fibers. Its notable side effect is gastrointestinal upset. 
❌ Procainamide:
Incorrect: Procainamide is a class IA antiarrhythmic that works in the same manner as disopyramide via fast sodium channel blockade. It is a known cause of drug-induced lupus. 
❌ Quinidine:
Incorrect: Quinidine is a class IA antiarrhythmic that works in the same manner as disopyramide via fast sodium channel blockade. It is known to cause cinchonism, which is characterized by headaches and tinnitus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction. The patient undergoes a percutaneous coronary artery angiography with stent placement in the left anterior descending artery. Three days later, the patient reports new-onset chest pain relieved by leaning forward and worsens with deep inspiration. The patient has no shortness of breath, lightheadedness or abdominal pain. Temperature is 37.2C (98.9F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a friction rub over the left sternal border. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The patient is treated with aspirin, resulting in significant relief of his symptoms. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of pleuritic chest pain following a recent myocardial infarction is suggestive of post-myocardial infarction pericarditis. Although most patients improve with supportive measures, patients with persistent symptoms can be managed with aspirin and colchicine.  

Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) works by irreversibly inhibiting both COX-1 and COX-2 (via acetylation).  This is in contrast to reversible COX inhibitors (non-aspirin NSAIDs) which can be further subdivided into 2 groups: non-selective COX inhibitors (e.g. ibuprofen), and selective COX-2 inhibitors (e.g. celecoxib).  

Once absorbed, aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX-1 in platelets via covalent acetylation, decreasing the production of thromboxane A2–making it useful as an antiplatelet medication. Since aspirin irreversibly prevents the platelets from synthesizing new COX-1 enzymes, its effects persist until new platelets are produced. Ultimately, this is reflected in an increased bleeding time without affecting the prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT). In addition, aspirin exerts additional antiinflammatory effects in the liver–resulting in decreased production of pro-inflammatory prostaglandin production.  



Option Analysis

✅ Irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phosphodiesterase III inhibitor:
Incorrect: Phosphodiesterase inhibitors break down cAMP in platelets and promote platelet aggregation. Phosphodiesterase inhibitors such as cilostazol and dipyridamole are antiplatelet agents used in the treatment of claudication, stroke prophylaxis and stable angina. They are not effective in the management of post-myocardial infarction pericarditis.
❌ Vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Warfarin serves as a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor used for chronic anticoagulation. It is not used to relieve chest pain associated with post-myocardial infarction pericarditis.
❌ Reversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as diclofenac and ibuprofen are reversible cyclooxygenase inhibitors. 
❌ Xanthine oxidase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor and used in the management of chronic gout. It does not relieve chest pain associated with post-myocardial infarction pericarditis.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent following a suicide attempt. The patient ingested some of her parent’s medication 10 hours ago. The parent has a medical history of osteoarthritis and coronary artery disease. The patient reports nausea, abdominal pain and ringing in ears. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 40/min and blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg. Laboratory results are shown below. Chest and abdominal x-rays are unremarkable. Which of the following medications was most likely ingested by this patient?  

 Laboratory value  Result
 Arterial blood gas
 pH  7.41 
 PaCO2  23 mmHg 
 Serum chemistry
 Sodium  141 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.6 mEq/L 
 Chloride   100 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  14 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of tinnitus, fever, tachypnea and gastrointestinal irritation, in combination with an anion gap (AG) metabolic acidosis, is consistent with salicylate intoxication.     

Early symptoms of salicylate poisoning include tinnitus, deafness, headache, and vomiting. At high doses, salicylate can directly stimulate the respiratory center–inducing hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis.   

With large ingestions salicylates inhibit oxidative phosphorylation–forcing metabolism to switch to the anaerobic pathway, producing lactic acid, and an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis. As blood pH decreases, salicylates shift towards its non-ionized form, salicylic acid, which easily crosses the blood-brain barrier inducing seizures or coma.  

While there is no specific antidote for aspirin overdose, management includes administration of activated charcoal to bind aspirin and prevents its absorption in the GI tract. In addition, alkalization of urine by administration of sodium bicarbonate facilitates salicylate excretion. Additional interventions include ventilatory support and management of the acid-base imbalance.  

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acute acetaminophen toxicity can present with nausea and vomiting; however, anion-gap metabolic acidosis and tinnitus are more consistent with salicylate toxicity.   
❌ Iron:
Incorrect: Large amounts of ingested iron damages the mucosa of the intestinal tract and usually presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea and gastrointestinal bleeding (melena/hematemesis). Iron tablets are usually visualized on plain abdominal x-ray (unlike aspirin).  
❌ Lead:
Incorrect: Acute lead poisoning can manifest with abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting; however, anion-gap metabolic acidosis and tinnitus are more consistent with salicylate toxicity.   
❌ Oxycodone:
Incorrect: Patients with narcotic (e.g. oxycodone) overdose typically present with a depressed respiratory rate, in contrast to this patient’s increased respiratory rate, suggestive of salicylate overdose.  
✅ Aspirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents for evaluation of joint pain, which has been ongoing for the past 4-months. The patient also noticed that she is sweating more excessively and her voice has gotten deeper. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 152/80 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min. Physical examination reveals frontal bossing, protrusion of the jaw, and multiple skin tags on the patient’s back. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Oral glucose fails to suppress growth hormone levels. Head CT confirms a pituitary mass. The patient declines surgical intervention and is started on pegvisomant. Which of the following is expected to be seen in this patient as a result of this medication?

Laboratory Value
Result
Hemoglobin
12.8 g/dL
Hematocrit
45%
Blood glucose
180 mg/dL
IGF-1
Elevated
Growth hormone
Elevated

choices.text: Decreased insulin like growth factor-1 levels.
Increased insulin like growth factor levels.

questions.solution:
This patient has physical examination, imaging, and laboratory findings consistent with acromegaly. Most cases of acromegaly are due to growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas. The first-line treatment option is transsphenoidal resection of the adenoma, which has excellent outcomes in controlling the disease and normalizing growth hormone (GH) levels. However, medical treatment is available for patients who are poor fit for surgery, refuse surgery, or have an unresectable adenoma. The options of medical treatment for acromegaly include:  

  • Somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide, lanreotide): Somatostatin analogs are effective in the treatment of acromegaly. These agents inhibit growth hormone secretion, thus controlling the symptoms and complications of excessive growth hormone. Furthermore, somatostatin analogs have been shown to induce shrinkage of pituitary adenomas. Side effects of this drug class include bloating, loose stools, fat malabsorption. In addition, there is increased risk of gallstones due to gallbladder hypomotility.  

  • GH-receptor antagonist (e.g. pegvisomant): Pegvisomant is a newly developed medication that has been shown to be efficacious in treating acromegaly. It binds to GH receptors and prevents their activation. Also, as it blocks GH receptors in hepatocytes, it prevents the production of IGF-1. Since pegvisomant does not suppress GH hormone production, a minority of patients may experience an increase in the size of the adenoma due to increased GH production. It can rarely cause increased liver enzymes, which usually normalizes after stopping the medication. 

  • Dopamine agonists (e.g. cabergoline): Dopamine agonists have been shown to decrease growth hormone secretion from pituitary adenomas. It can be used alone or in combination with somatostatin analogs. Side effects include nausea, lightheadedness, depression and constipation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased insulin like growth factor-1 levels.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Decreased growth hormone levels  :
Incorrect: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist that leads to decreased insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels. The decrease in IGF-1 levels leads to a loss of negative feedback, resulting in an increase in pituitary growth hormone production.
❌ Decreased adenoma size  :
Incorrect: Adenoma size decreases in patients who are taking somatostatin analogs (e.g. octreotide) or undergoing radiation therapy. In contrast, this patient is started on pegvisomant, which is a growth hormone receptor antagonist that leads to decreased insulin growth factor-1 (IGF-1) production. The decrease in IGF-1 levels leads to a loss of negative feedback, resulting in an increase in pituitary growth hormone production and pituitary size.  
❌ Increased insulin like growth factor levels.  :
Incorrect: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone (GH) receptor antagonist. Therefore, it blocks the binding of GH to hepatocytes and results in decreased insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) production.   
❌ Increased blood glucose levels  :
Incorrect: Growth hormone (GH) is a diabetogenic hormone that causes insulin resistance and increased blood glucose levels. Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist that results in decreased blood glucose levels.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual physical examination. The patient has left hip pain, attributed to Paget disease of the bone diagnosed three years ago. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. The patient is allergic to penicillin. Her last menstrual period was ten years ago. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is given the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine and shingles vaccine. A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan reveals a T-score of -2.7. The patient inquires about a new PTH-analogue, teriparatide. Which of the following is a contraindication to this medication in this patient?

choices.text: Personal history of Paget disease of the bone

questions.solution:
This patient’s DEXA scan reveals a T-score of -2.7, which is consistent with a diagnosis of osteoporosis. Teriparatide is an effective treatment option for postmenopausal osteoporosis. It is, however, contraindicated in this patient given her history of Paget disease of the bone.  

Teriparatide is a recombinant analog of the parathyroid hormone given subcutaneously once per day. When given in a pulsatile fashion, it works by stimulating osteoblasts and reducing their apoptosis, resulting in a net increase in bone formation.    

Common side effects include transient hypercalcemia and an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. The medication should be avoided when the patient has other diseases that also increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma, such as those with Paget disease of bone.  




Option Analysis

❌ Family history of breast cancer:
Incorrect: Family history of breast cancer is not a contraindication to teriparatide.  
✅ Personal history of Paget disease of the bone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent pneumococcal vaccine administration:
Incorrect: Interaction between a vaccine and a drug has been reported only with the influenza vaccine and four drugs, which are aminopyrine, phenytoin sodium, theophylline, and warfarin sodium. The pneumococcal vaccine does not interact with teriparatide.  
❌ Penicillin allergy:
Incorrect: There is no cross-reactivity between penicillin and teriparatide.  
❌ Postmenopausal state:
Incorrect: Teriparatide is a suitable medication for treating postmenopausal osteoporosis. The medication can be safely administered to women in a postmenopausal state.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for routine follow-up in the springtime. The patient reports frequent sneezing, rhinorrhea and watery eyes since she started training for an upcoming marathon. Past medical history is also notable for well-controlled asthma. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler on an as-needed basis. The patient does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F ), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows a prominent nasal crease. The nasal turbinates are boggy and bluish-gray. There is a copious thin and watery nasal mucus. The physician starts the patient on oral loratadine. The mechanism of this medication is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sneezing, rhinorrhea and watery eyes consistent with allergic rhinitis.  Allergic rhinitis is an example of a Type I, or IgE mediated hypersensitivity reaction. Histamine is a small molecule stored in mast cells and basophils that mediates allergic, inflammatory and other physiologic processes throughout the body by binding to four different receptors (H1, H2, H3, H4).  Histamine plays an important role in Type I hypersensitivity reactions by binding to H1 receptors, causing local inflammation and vasodilation.

In a Type 1 allergic reaction, an allergen, such as pollen, enters the body and activates B cells. Activated B-cells produce IgE antibodies that get released into the bloodstream and bind to mast cells. The mast cells are now “primed,” meaning that if pollen enters the body again in the future, the mast cells degranulate and release their histamine into the local tissue.

Antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine and loratadine) reduce itching, sneezing, and rhinorrhea by blocking H1 receptors on endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, sensory nerve endings, and in the brain.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Antagonism of H1 receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Antagonism of H2 receptors:
Incorrect: H2 antagonists target the H2 receptors found in gastric parietal cells.  They are effective in the treatment of gastroesophageal reflux and peptic ulcers by blocking gastric acid secretion, but are not useful in the treatment of allergic rhinitis.  
❌ Stimulation of somatostatin receptors:
Incorrect: Somatostatin receptors agonists (e.g. octreotide) inhibit bioactive amine release and are used to treat diarrhea in patients with carcinoid syndrome and VIPoma.  
❌ Antagonism of nicotinic receptors:
Incorrect: Nicotinic receptor antagonists (e.g. rocuronium) are used to induce paralysis in preparation for surgery and endotracheal intubation. They are not effective in allergic rhinitis.  
❌ Antagonism of serotonin 5-HT3 receptors:
Incorrect: Serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonists (e.g. ondansetron) are used primarily to treat nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office because of a five-day history of high fevers. The fevers occur intermittently, and he has not noticed a pattern as to when they occur. The fevers are accompanied by muscle aches, chills, and night sweats. He lives in Massachusetts and recently returned from a global surgery trip to Africa. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with metformin. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Peripheral blood smear reveals trophozoites and schizonts. After further evaluation, the patient is started on high-dose quinine. This medication is associated with which of the following side effects?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an irregular pattern of fevers, chills, and myalgias after returning from a malaria-endemic area. In addition, a blood smear reveals trophozoites and schizonts. These findings are concerning for Plasmodium falciparum infection. The patient is started on high-dose quinine therapy and is at increased risk of developing cinchonism, which constellates gastrointestinal distress, headache, vertigo, blurred vision, and tinnitus symptoms.

Apart from quinine, other quinoline-based antimalarial medications include quinidine and chloroquine. These medications can all cause gastrointestinal distress and headaches. Quinidine can also cause cinchonism as well as arrhythmias and long QT syndrome. As a result, the medication should be avoided in individuals with cardiac problems. Chloroquine can cause pruritus and, if used over long periods, can cause retinopathy, which is reversible if the medication is stopped.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Nocturnal leg cramps:
Incorrect: Quinine is moderately effective in decreasing the frequency and intensity of muscle cramps. As a result, nocturnal leg cramps are not a side effect of quinine therapy.  
❌ Diabetic retinopathy:
Incorrect: Quinine is not known to cause diabetic retinopathy.  
✅ Cinchonism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Idiopathic intracranial hypertension:
Incorrect: Tetracycline, vitamin A derivatives, and oral contraceptives, but not quinine, are associated with an increased risk of developing idiopathic intracranial hypertension.  
❌ Psychosis and seizure:
Incorrect: Oral mefloquine is generally well tolerated. However, the United States FDA has added a “black box” warning to mefloquine, noting the drug’s potential to cause severe, possibly permanent, neurological and psychiatric adverse effects. However, quinine therapy has not been associated with these side effects.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of intermittent fevers, chills, malaise, and fatigue for the past seven days. The patient returned from his cousin’s wedding in Africa three weeks ago. The patient was prescribed chemoprophylaxis but did not take it regularly. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctiva and an enlarged spleen. Peripheral blood smear shows trophozoites and schizonts. Appropriate treatment is started, and the patient is discharged. He returns to the emergency department 2-days later following a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. His partner, accompanying him, recalls that the patient showed signs of improvement until the seizure. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s complication?
questions.solution:
This patient was started on an antimalarial regimen that likely included mefloquine, often used with artesunate to treat chloroquine-resistant malaria.

Common adverse effects of mefloquine include gastrointestinal distress, skin rash, headache, and dizziness. Mefloquine can cause cardiac conduction defects and neuropsychiatric complications (e.g., seizures, psychosis, depression).  

Option Analysis

❌ Primaquine:
Incorrect: Primaquine can cause hemolytic anemia in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate-dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency and is contraindicated in pregnancy. However, it is not associated with neurological complications such as seizures.  
❌ Chloroquine:
Incorrect: Chloroquine can cause pruritus and its long term use can cause retinopathy. It is not associated with neurological complications such as seizures.  
❌ Quinine:
Incorrect: Quinine has been associated with cinchonism, a constellation of gastrointestinal distress, headache, vertigo, blurred vision, and tinnitus. In addition, the medication is associated with an increased risk of arrhythmias and long QT syndrome.  
✅ Mefloquine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline is a tetracycline associated with esophageal ulceration, photosensitivity, and gastrointestinal discomfort. It is not associated with an increased risk of seizures.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate due to altered mental status. According to the roommate, the patient appeared confused and mumbled about how “spies” were trying to sabotage her homework assignment. Past medical history is notable for depression for which she takes fluoxetine. Earlier in the day, the patient visited her university health clinic due to cold symptoms and was prescribed an antitussive. Temperature is 40.2°C (104.4°F), blood pressure is 157/96 mmHg, and pulse is 126/min. The patient is oriented to self but not place or time. The skin appears flushed and is warm to touch. 4+ reflexes are elicited in the upper and lower extremities. What is the primary mechanism of action of the antitussive responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, autonomic instability, and hyperreflexia. She has been taking fluoxetine and was started on a new antitussive. Together, these findings are concerning for serotonin syndrome. The new medication was most likely dextromethorphan, which works primarily by antagonizing NMDA receptors but also exerts serotonergic effects.     

Dextromethorphan is an antitussive that can be used to relieve cough caused by minor viral upper respiratory tract infections or inhaled irritants. It acts primarily by antagonizing NMDA glutamate receptors. This medication is a codeine-analog and has mild opioid effects when used in excess. As a result, the medication carries mild abuse potential. Moreover, dextromethorphan can inhibit serotonin reuptake and can precipitate serotonin syndrome, especially when taken in combination with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).    

Side effects, particularly with overdose, include hallucinations, confusion, euphoria, nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus. In severe cases, patients may experience seizures, coma, and respiratory depression.     

Option Analysis

❌ Stimulation of muscarinic receptors:
Incorrect: Guaifenesin stimulates muscarinic receptors, which in turn, triggers submucosal glands to produce well-hydrated secretions. Guaifenesin is an expectorant, not an antitussive. Furthermore, guaifenesin would not precipitate serotonin syndrome.  
✅ Blockade of NMDA receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Disruption of disulfide bonds:
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic that thins mucus by disrupting disulfide bonds. N-acetylcysteine is neither an antitussive nor would it precipitate serotonin syndrome when used in combination with fluoxetine.  
❌ Antagonization of H1 receptors:
Incorrect: Antihistamines (e.g. diphenhydramine, loratadine, cetirizine) prevent respiratory smooth muscle constriction and mucus production. These medications can be used to treat symptoms of nasal congestion caused by allergies or the common cold. Antihistamines would not trigger serotonin syndrome when used in combination with fluoxetine.  
❌ Inhibition of monoamine oxidase activity:
Incorrect: Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (e.g. phenelzine, tranylcypromine) are antidepressants that increase serotonin levels and can precipitate serotonin syndrome. However, this patient’s symptoms developed after starting a new antitussive, not a new antidepressant.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to an employee health fair at the hospital where she works as a nurse. The patient is feeling well and does not have any symptoms. Her past medical history is notable for asthma, for which she intermittently uses an albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 123/78 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. A purified protein derivative injection is performed, and after two days, a wheal measuring 12 mm in diameter is observed at the injection site. The patient is started on a medication that can cause side effects, including elevations in liver enzymes, reduced sensation in the extremities, and the development of a malar rash. Which of the following best describes this medication’s mechanism of action?

choices.text: Generation of free radicals that damage DNA

questions.solution:
This asymptomatic patient works in a healthcare setting and has a positive tuberculin skin test. She likely has latent tuberculosis and was initiated on isoniazid, which can cause hepatotoxicity, peripheral neuropathy, and drug-induced lupus.  

Isoniazid can be used as monotherapy for prophylaxis or treatment of latent tuberculosis. It can be used in combination with other medications to treat active tuberculosis. Isoniazid is converted by the mycobacterial enzyme catalase-peroxidase into its active metabolite iproniazid, inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis. The medication also inhibits mycobacterial peroxidase and prevents the bacteria from metabolizing hydrogen peroxide, which accumulates intracellularly, causing damage to the cell. Mycobacteria can develop resistance if mutations form in the catalase-peroxidase gene.    

Side effects of isoniazid include rash, fever, and drug-induced lupus. It can also cause vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency, which leads to sideroblastic anemia. Pyridoxine deficiency also leads to neurological symptoms, including dizziness, ataxia, or encephalopathy, but the most common is peripheral neuropathy. Fortunately, these side effects can be prevented with the concurrent administration of pyridoxine. Isoniazid can also cause hepatotoxicity and inhibit cytochrome P450. Finally, in overdose cases, the drug can cause seizures, anion gap metabolic acidosis, and coma.  



Option Analysis

❌ Blockade of arabinogalactan synthesis:
Incorrect: Ethambutol inhibits the enzyme arabinosyltransferase, thereby preventing the synthesis of arabinogalactan–a component of the mycobacterial cell wall. Ethambutol can cause optic neuritis and hyperuricemia. However, it would not account for the constellation of side effects described in the question stem.  
❌ Inhibition of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase:
Incorrect: Rifampin is an antituberculosis drug that works by inhibiting mycobacterial RNA polymerase. Although this drug can cause hepatitis and elevated liver enzymes, it would not typically cause peripheral neuropathy or drug-induced lupus.  
❌ Generation of free radicals that damage DNA:
Incorrect: Metronidazole is an antibiotic that generates free radicals, which can damage bacterial and protozoal DNA. This medication can treat protozoal (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica, Giardia lamblia) and anaerobic bacterial infections. However, metronidazole is not used to treat tuberculosis and would not cause drug-induced lupus or peripheral neuropathy.  
❌ Blockade of bacterial ribosomal 30S subunit:
Incorrect: Aminoglycosides, such as streptomycin, act on the 30S subunit of mycobacterial ribosomes, thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. Side effects of these medications include rash, fever, ototoxicity, and ataxia. Aminoglycosides are not used as monotherapy for the treatment of tuberculosis. Furthermore, they would not account for the constellation of side effects described in the question stem.  
✅ Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to her outpatient provider to evaluate muscle pain and tightness. These symptoms are most prominent in the lower extremities and worsen with movement. She currently has difficulty ambulating and requires assistance with a walker. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and poorly-controlled multiple sclerosis. She experiences multiple acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis each year and currently takes glatiramer acetate. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 148/93 mmHg, and pulse is 67/min. Increased muscle tone is present in the bilateral lower extremities on physical examination. There is resistance to active and passive range of motion in the foot and ankle joints, which is more prominent with rapid movements. The patient is started on a new medication to treat muscle spasticity. This medication’s side effects include hyporeflexia, sedation, and tolerance with prolonged use. Which of the following best describes this medication’s mechanism of action?

choices.text: Activation of GABA receptors within the spinal cord
Inhibition of ryanodine receptors in muscle cells
Induction of B-cell and T-cell apoptosis
Antagonization of 5-HT2 receptors within the spinal cord

questions.solution:
This patient with multiple sclerosis presents with muscle spasticity, defined as a velocity-dependent increase. Baclofen therapy can be used for symptomatic management.

Baclofen is a muscle relaxant that activates presynaptic and postsynaptic γ-aminobutyric acid b (GABA b) receptors within the spinal cord. In the presynaptic membrane, baclofen increases potassium efflux and reduces calcium influx, leading to decreased excitatory neurotransmitter glutamic acid release.
